content.data: Modifications
image2045.gif
There are 5 Modifications options:
image992.gif
Overrides
image2047.gif
The Overrides option will display any Overrides that have been placed on the current Assembly. You can remove them by highlighting the item in the list and clicking the Remove button.
image.png
Default Assembly
image2049.gif

A default Assembly is an Assembly that has been reconstructed by Solid at the Assembly Level, following the information you have entered in the  Assembly Manager  and  Assembly Parts Material Schedule  for the Assembly in question. Additionally, the Assembly is absent features such as Face configuration and Interior options. It is, in short, a box built exactly as you specified when you setup the Construction Method that is effective for the Assembly. Another advantage is that the Default Assembly sheds any unintentional overrides that may have accidentally become part of the Assembly. In practice, it is probably a good idea to begin the process of sectioning an Assembly into a unique configuration by first defaulting the Assembly.

Also note there are two options when Defaulting an Assembly. By default the Default Assembly option will not Remove an Assemblies Shape or any user Added or user Modified Parameters. If you would like them removed as well simply enable these options.
image1.png
After defaulting the Assembly, it will appear similarly to the Base Cabinet below.
image448.jpg
Adjust Parts
image2050.gif
The Adjust Parts option allows you to make dimensional and/or positional changes to standard Assembly (Default Assembly) Parts.
There are six main options in the Case Part Adjustments area:
image926.gif

Top Depth -  Enter a value here to add to or subtract from the current  Top  Depth. 
 
 
 Bottom Depth -  Enter a value here to add to or subtract from the current  Bottom  Depth. 
 
 
 Back

As an example of how this may be used, assume a Wall Cabinet above the refrigerator needs to have ends that extend to the floor. There are several methods to create this Cabinet, however, using the Parts Adjustment menu allows an easy method to create the new feature. Because the Cabinet is 69 inches off the floor, I need the ends to increase in length 69 inches. By placing that value in the box marked "Height" for each End, Right and Left, I have increased the length of the ends to 84 inches (69 plus the original 15). The result entering the value in the Height box for both Ends is shown on the graphic below.
image446.jpg
Hide Parts
image2051.gif
image2.png

Parts that are added to an Assembly by Solid that are a part of the Assembly Construction Method are referred to as system Parts. Typically, system Parts lack a "delete" feature for removal. The Hide Parts option allows hiding Parts by placing a check in the box next to the Part to be hidden. To restore a hidden Part, re-access this option and remove the check mark. Notice that the Parts are grouped. Check marks in the group will hide all Parts within the group. If you want to hide only Front Toes, you would not benefit from clicking the Toe Parts group as all Toe Parts would be hidden, instead, select "Front Toe" from the Toe Parts Group and limit the hide to the specific Part you need to hide.
Please note that the keyword here is  " Hide "  the Assembly still reacts and is constructed as if the Part were still visible.
Warning.png
Reverse Assembly
image991.gif
This option will Reverse/Mirror the current Assembly.
Reverse Assembly, at this time,  will not  Reverse user modifications and overrides, this would include user added Parts and Formulas.
Warning.png
